HPL ST.question: The crew of an executive jet belonging to a very well-known and respected charter company were acknowlegdged by all to be the most experienced crew in the entire company. Over time they had become so familiar with this particular aircraft type that they could do all the pre-flight checks without looking at a checklist or using the challenge and response technique. Unfortunately, on this occasion, they overlooked an important item and attempted to take off with the control locks engaged. They aborted the take-off but slightly overran the runway. None of the passengers or crew were injured but the aircraft's landing gear was severely damaged. After listening to the CVR and ascertaining the facts, the company dismissed both crew from their employment. Which of the following statements most accurately describes the safety culture in this organisation?
choices: The operator appropriately applied the principle of just culture, fairly punishing this negligent behaviour. This sent a firm message to all its crew that such violations would never be tolerated by the organisation, regardless of the seniority and past record of those involved.

This is a poor example of a just culture. Throughout their very long careers the captain and first officer had never had an accident. They had learned their lesson from this one and knew that in future they must follow the checklist procedures. Punishment in this case was inappropriate.Instead, the chief pilot should have publicised the incident so that all crew would be sure not to make the same mistake in the future
This is a good example of a just culture because the company was emphasising that no error would be tolerated, regardless of the experience of the crew.
This is a good example of an 'open culture' because the dismissal of the crew was made known to all to ensure that no other crew would commit the same error in the future
HPL ST.answer: This is a poor example of a just culture. Throughout their very long careers the captain and first officer had never had an accident. They had learned their lesson from this one and knew that in future they must follow the checklist procedures. Punishment in this case was inappropriate.Instead, the chief pilot should have publicised the incident so that all crew would be sure not to make the same mistake in the future

HPL ST.question: Whilst pushing back from a dark, poorly lit stand at night the (inexperienced) first officer was responsible to confirming adequate starboard wing-tip clearance from a nearby engineer's cabin. The wing-tip walker made no indication that the wing-tip clearance was inadequate. Unfortunately, the aircraft's wing-tip came into contact with the roof of the cabin, sustaining minor damage. The captain abandoned the flight and reported the incident to the chief pilot, emphasising that it had been the first officer's responsibility to ensure adequate tip clearance not his and that he should be punished for his error. The chief pilot interviewed the first officer and decided to take no disciplinary action against him. Instead, without publicly referring to the captain's assessment he made it a company SOP no longer to use this stand. He also published a note to all crew describing what had happened and explaining that, regardless of any wing walker's signals, the crew is responsible for obstacle clearance. If there's any doubt they should stop and clarify the situation. Which of the following statements most accurately describes the safety culture in this organisation?
choices: This is an example of a closed culture because the chief pilot did not publicise the fact that he disagreed with the captain’s assessment. Instead, he secretly overrode the captain’s recommendation.

This is an example of a just culture in which trust is built. This was an unintentional error made by an inexperienced first officer and so should not be punished. Instead, all crew would benefit from the learning experience.
This is not an example of a just culture because the chief pilot failed to back up the captain thus undermining the trust between the two and demeaning the captain’s authority.
This is a good example of a reporting culture because the captain felt able to report the first officer’s violation without fear of reprisals on himself.
HPL ST.answer: This is an example of a just culture in which trust is built. This was an unintentional error made by an inexperienced first officer and so should not be punished. Instead, all crew would benefit from the learning experience.
